keyTakeAways: The outage originated from a technical update to DynamoDB's API in AWS's Virginia data center, causing a DNS failure that disrupted connections to critical cloud services.
Over 113 AWS services were impacted, including major platforms such as Snapchat, Pinterest, Apple TV, WhatsApp, Zoom, Roblox, Fortnite, Starbucks, and financial apps like Venmo.
The root cause was human error during a routine update, not a cyberattack or external threat, as confirmed by cybersecurity expert Bryson Bort.
The failure underscores how deeply dependent modern digital services are on cloud infrastructure, especially AWS, which dominates 30% of the global cloud market.
AWS responded quickly by engaging engineers on multiple recovery paths and confirmed full resolution, though some users experienced delays in service restoration.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A major AWS outage began at 07:11 GMT due to a flawed technical update to DynamoDB’s API in AWS’s Virginia data center, which triggered a DNS failure and caused widespread disruption across 113 services. This included major platforms such as Snapchat, WhatsApp, Zoom, Roblox, Fortnite, financial apps like Venmo, and news organizations like The New York Times. The root cause was identified as human error, not a cyberattack. AWS responded quickly, with all services restored by 10:11 GMT, though some users faced delays. The incident underscores the critical dependence of modern digital services—ranging from banking and gaming to media and smart home devices—on centralized cloud infrastructure, and highlights the importance of robust error-handling and redundancy in such systems.
title: What caused Amazon’s AWS outage, and why did so many major apps go offline?
